description.en-US: Our operating profit at the bank has decreased steadily over time and we are now a whole 5 percentage points below our main competitors. This is clearly a concern for our board, who have asked us to come up with a plan to address this situation. We need to either our customer representatives to sell more and our back office staff to process work faster, or we need to find places to cut costs.</br>Here are some alternatives that our board would approve. What should we do?

title.en-US: We don't seem to understand our customers

description.en-US: Our competitors are getting a lot of traction for their new apps, while our customers seem to ignore our new services. One board member noted that our technology development unit seems too disconnected from our customers and the everyday issues our customer representatives deal with. Another board member suggested that our new services may be focusing on the customers’ current problems rather than their fundamental needs. Whatever the reasons are, it appears we are not as customer centric as we should be. </br>Maybe we should try one of these approaches?

title.en-US: The board wants an agile transformation

description.en-US: Our research and development efforts have led to a number of promising new services, but the current organization doesn’t seem to facilitate innovation. In fact, there seems to be a complete lack of alignment in realizing the new services and getting our customers to use them. Part of the problem is ignorance—our organization is not aware of the new services and the customer needs they address. Finally, our customer-facing employees are more interested in maintaining old relationships than pushing out our new services.

The adoption of the agile structure has led to increase in political conflicts. Many former leaders have trouble adapting to a more collegial and non-hierarchical decision making practices. Individiuals are using their social networks and status to steamroll their own ideas through.

The multi-functional R&D teams are great at coming up with customer-oriented solutions, but their work seems to be all over the place. The services are partially overlapping and they do not really complement one other. The company seems to be losing its direction.

Employees love the ability of their teams to make a real difference, and our customer feedback has increased. Not all is going well though. Our people are working insane hours and many leaders report a sense of impending burn-out. It seems that the teams are doing a lot of duplicate work, solving problems that have already been solved by other teams. How could we help coordinate work better?

The transformation process is well on the way, but there seem to be a few hiccups. First, employees in some teams do not seem to know what to do exactly and they are waiting for instructions.

After talking with some employees, we believe that former managers are still very influential. Former subordinates are waiting to be instructed by their former managers on what to do beyong the team boundaries.

title.en-US: Lack of alignment and duplicate work

Some of our back office employees are close to retirement age and we could invest in new software systems to automate some of the more routine human work taking place there.

We could reduce the number of customer representatives by expanding the functionality of our website and mobile applications, encouraging customers to carry out some of the tasks themselves that are now conducted by our employees.

Our current pay has a very limited performance-based component. By shifting towards more performance-oriented pay scheme, especially for customer representatives, we can motivate our employees to sell more and thereby increase our income. This should also boost our operating profit.

toolTip.en-US: Employee ability to perform routine work in minimal time and maximum effect.
The ability of the organization to identify and react to new opportunities and changing customer needs.
The organization is able to coordinate activities and innovation across unit boundaries.
Employee initiative and involvement in the business.
The replacement of routine human work with automated processes.
Employee motivation in absence of explicit rewards and bonuses.
The extent to which employees can make decisions without permission from higher-level managers.
The degree of conflict in the organiation.
The extent to which authority is based on formal position (rather than expertise, networks, or situated negoations).

description.en-US: The organization has established multi-functional teams responsible for developing new digital solutions.
Smart software is now taking care of many routine tasks, freeing employees to focus on creative work.
The bank is organized as a ’team of teams.’ In practice, the bank's activities are divided into six ’tribes’ that each consist of 6-12 multifunctional squads.

The company has adopted contemporary collaboration tools, such as chat rooms, internal social media, and advanced search engines that help employees share knowledge across teams and find answers to their solutions.

To facilitate collaboration, the company now shares details of all major projects as well as personal goals of all managers on its intranet. Most employees have access to information about cost, revenues, and profit margins of various services and employee groups to facilitate intelligent business development efforts and corporate entrepreneurship.
